processing this directive]                                                                                                               Fishing                                                                                           On the PSICC, we offer the angler many opportunities to experience              the fine fishing we have available. Our forests and grasslands offer              both warm and cold water fishing across an incredibly diverse              landscape.                             The PSICC manages over 2.3 million acres of public lands              southeastern Colorado and Kansas, from high-plains short-grass              prairies in the east to the towering 14,000 ft peaks of the              Collegiate and Mosquito ranges in the west. We are responsible for              over 4,000 miles of perennial rivers and streams, as well as              hundreds of high mountain lakes.                             We are also the home of the rare               Greenback Cutthroat trout  (Oncorhynchus clarki stomias), the              Colorado State fish, which is listed as threatened both Federally              and by the State. Currently, one of the greatest threats to fishing              opportunities on our forests is the spread of               whirling disease .                             Please visit our               Whirling disease page  for information on how you can help us              prevent the spread of this pernicious parasite. As you use our site,              we hope you find much useful information to guide you in your              fishing exploits.                             Good Luck! Keyword/Phrase Search          Advanced Search                                                        What does it cost to use data, photos or images from Recreation.gov?                                                                        Photo                Credit: US Fish and Wildlife Service                Clear Lake National Wildlife Refuge in California                    Almost all the data on Recreation.gov is free and available for your use, with a few major qualifiers:    Use of official agency logos is restricted.  Do not copy them onto your website without permission.   Some images may be copyrighted - if so, that restriction is noted.  Contact the agency responsible for that facility with the restricted image to obtain permission for use.  Once you follow a link off the Recreation.gov website, the rights to use the data, photos or images are determined by the managers of that different system.  Do not assume that data on other systems is in the public domain; copyright restrictions may apply.     There is no fee for using the data from Recreation.gov, and no need to contact us to obtain formal permission for incorporating the public domain data, photos, or images into your computer system/website. The text descriptions in the Recreation.gov database is in the public domain. You may add that text to your web pages, or "deep link" to a Recreation.gov page with frames surrounding the Recreation.gov information.           In exchange, we request that you provide a link to Recreation.gov and credit the source, such as:    Source of Data: Recreation.gov   or  Source of Image: Recreation.gov   Feel free to use this graphic as well:       The data is provided at no cost in order to encourage wide distribution and regular updates to different publications, databases, and websites, so customers can receive correct information from many different systems.  Recreation.gov is an electronic government ("e-gov") initiative that demonstrates the advantages of using a data standard based on an XML Schema and data exchange via Web services.   Eliminating costs wherever possible and simplifying the data exchange process will facilitate dissemination of consistent, reliable information.
